completedText: Congratulations! You found and learned about the 8 Bedroom Triggers and Ways to Avoid!! Now you are going into the next room (is it the Living Room. Enjoy finding and learning!!

targets.Name: Cat
postText:
Allergen – Pet Hair and Dander (Cat)

FURRY PETS (Ex: Dogs, Cats, Hamsters, Guinea Pigs, and Rabbits) are common allergens that can trigger asthma symptoms in some people.

  • Pet hair and dander can fly in the air and land on your pillow and clothing.

  • When your pet sleeps on your bed, you’re sleeping in their shed fur.

Allergen – Pet Hair and Dander (Cat)

Furry pets: How to avoid exposure or reduce this trigger

  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms and off furniture.

  • Wash furry pets often to remove allergens.

  • Change clothes with pet hair on it to avoid transferring pet hair and dander from clothing to bedding, carpets etc.

  • Wash linens, blankets, curtains, and stuffed toys frequently to decrease allergens in rooms. Dust with a damp cloth.
Text:
FURRY PETS (Ex: Dogs, Cats, Hamsters, Guinea Pigs, and Rabbits) are common pet allergens that can trigger asthma symptoms in some people.

Pet hair and dander, especially cat hair, can fly in the air and land on surfaces throughout the house...

postText:
Physical activity can trigger asthma symptoms for some people.

It is also known as exercise-induced bronchoconstriction/asthma (EIB/EIA)

It is described as problems with breathing during &/or after exercise.

Exercising in extreme air temperatures or poor air quality can worsen this for some people.

To stay healthy it is important to exercise. 

Some people with asthma are prescribed medication to treat these symptoms so they can tolerate exercise. 

      How to avoid or reduce this trigger causing asthma

  • Talk to the health care provider to make an exercise plan.
  • Some people with asthma may need to take medication that helps keep their asthma in control when they exercise.
  • If premedication is prescribed, make sure it is available & taken as directed before all physical activities. (See the example on the backpack, now prepared with an inhaler and spacer)
  • Caution when exercise is outdoors, change in weather or airborne allergens & air quality can affect asthma too.
targets.Name: Sports
targets.hint: I can take your breath away if you’re not careful

targets.Name: Bed
postText:
Allergen – Dust Mites (Bedding)

DUST MITES are found in beds & bedding. 

  • Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Dust mites live in things made of thick fibers like bedding, carpets pillows, sofas, rugs and stuffed toys. 

  • Dust mites live and multiply in high humidity (high moisture).

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Cover mattress, box spring and pillows with allergy-proof zippered covers
  • Wash and dry all bedding on high heat every week
  • Keep indoor humidity low, best between 30-50%
  • Use hygrometers (found at hardware stores) to measure indoor humidity
  • Limit use of humidifiers or vaporizers as they can increase moisture in the bedroom
targets.hint: I’m so comfy you sleep with me every night

targets.Name: Dust
postText:
Allergen – Dust (Lamp)
DUST can make asthma symptoms worse for many people.

  • Dust is made of tiny particles from pollen, mold, pet dander and hair, dust mites, and pests.

  • Dust or pollen can be tracked in from outside. How clean is your entryway?

  • Some vacuum cleaners can spread dust back into the air.

Allergen – Dust (Lamp)

House dust: How to avoid or reduce this trigger

  • Vacuum when the person with asthma is NOT home as dust from vacuuming can spread back into the air.

  • Empty the dirt from the vacuum cleaner carefully to avoid spreading collected dust back into the air.

  • Change filters on central heating and air conditioning systems to help control dust.

  • Wipe all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week.
targets.hint: some say I'm spread around by a pixie, others say I'm a bunny,

targets.Name: StuffedAnimals
postText:
Allergen – Dust Mites (Stuffed Animals)

DUST MITES are found in stuffed toys. 

  • Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye.

  • Dust mites live in things made of thick fibers like bedding, carpets, pillows, sofas, rugs and stuffed toys. 

  • Dust mites live and multiply in high humidity (high moisture).

Dust mites in stuffed toys. How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid use of, or limit (suggest less than 3) stuffed toys in home.
  • No stuffed toy should be kept on the child’s bed.
  • Use only washable stuffed toys and wash and dry these weekly, you can place them in a plastic bag & freeze them overnight too.
  • Store washable stuffed toys in an airtight container out of the child’s bedroom
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%. Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers which you can buy at a local store or online for a low cost.

targets.Name: Perfume
postText:
Inhaled Irritants – Strong Odors (Perfume)

AEROSOL SPRAYS and strong odors (EX: perfume, hairspray, and cleaning products) are commonly used and found in homes.  

  • Aerosol sprays and strong odors are inhaled irritants that trigger asthma symptoms for some people.

  • Aerosol sprays and strong odors stay in the air after they are used.

  • Aerosol sprays and strong odors are breathed in.

How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid using aerosol sprays indoors
  • Avoid products with strong odors
  • Avoid products that are heavily scented
  • Air out the room where sprays are used

targets.Name: PollenCloud
postText:
Allergen – Pollen (Window)

POLLENS can blow in from outside. Pollens may trigger asthma symptoms in some people.  

  • Pollens can be in the air, outside as well as inside.

  • Pollens can land on surfaces inside the house.

  • Pollens can land on the outside and inside of cars.

Pollens: How to avoid or reduce this trigger

  • Keep windows closed especially during high pollen days.
  • Pay attention to pollen levels. Check online, TV or sign up for weather & pollen alerts
  • Do not dry laundry outdoors during high pollen hours
  • Limit time spent outdoors on high pollen days and times. Remove clothing worn outdoors before sitting or lying on indoor furniture & bedroom areas, shower before going to bed.  
  • Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week. Clean curtains, window treatments, and bedding often dust may contain pollens.
  • Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) to clean pollen dust.
  • Use window filters, or air conditioning, to filter out pollen in the air     
  • Hepa filter air purifiers may help reduce airborne pollens (AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)
targets.hint: I can fly for miles and land all over your stuff

targets.Name: Carpet
postText:
Allergen – Dust Mites (Rug)

DUST MITES are found in rugs and carpeting and can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye.

  • Rugs are made of thick fibers. Deep in the rug fibers it is dark and humid. This is a place where dust mites like to live.

Dust mites: How to avoid or reduce this trigger

  •  Remove rugs from the home
  • Replace rugs with tile or wood that can be damp mopped often
  • If you can’t take out the rugs, use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA). Vacuum often
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%. Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers which you can buy at a local store or online for a low cost
This is an alarm clock. It is not an asthma trigger. You're getting warmer, though!

targets.Name: Laptop
BookDust
postText:
Allergen – Dust (Books)

DUST is a common allergy trigger for some people with asthma and can cause asthma symptoms or make symptoms worse.

  • Dust is made of many tiny particles from pollens, mold, pet dander and hair, dust mites, and pests.

  • Dust can be found on many surfaces and objects.

  • Some vacuum cleaners can spread the dust around a room or in the air.

House dust: How to avoid or reduce this trigger

  • Vacuum when the person with asthma is NOT at home because dust from vacuuming can be spread back into the air.
  • Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) on carpet and fabric-covered furniture to reduce dust build-up and reduce the amount of dust coming out of the vacuum.
  • Be careful when emptying the dirt from the vacuum cleaner to avoid the collected dust spreading in the air.
  • Central heating and air conditioning systems may help control dust, change filters often.
  • Reduce clutter to help reduce dust.and Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week.             
  • Consider using a HEPA air purifier if airborne dust is a problem.     

(AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)
